concept.display: Very fit (strong, active, energetic, and motivated; exercise regularly; belong to the fittest for their age)
Fit (no active disease symptoms, but less fit than category 1; often engage in movement or are more active during seasonal activities)
Managing well (medical issues well under control; not regularly active aside from daily walks)
Low risk of frailty (not dependent on others for daily assistance; often experience complaints that limit daily activities; common complaint of feeling 'sluggish' and/or tired throughout the day)
Mildly frail (noticeably slower in movement or thinking; need assistance with more complex daily tasks such as finances, transportation, medication, or heavy household work)
Moderately frail (Need assistance with all activities outside the home and household; difficulties with stair climbing; need help with showering; some assistance needed with dressing)
Severely frail (completely dependent on others for personal care, both cognitively and physically; still appear stable; not at a high risk of death within 6 months)
Very severely frail (24/7 completely dependent; approaching end of life; unable to recover from even 'mild' illnesses; bedridden)
Terminal (life expectancy less than 6 months; no other clear frailty present)
